Jim,

I took the tsuba to shinsa, but may have not submitted
it. I believe the owner made a substitution (he had
only so many slots and given me more items than he had
slots). Same owner as the Myochin.

The design is exactly the same as Rich's, but it did
not feel Akasaka. The mimi on Akasaka usually feels
more full, rounded. Then the actual plate on the tsuba
was ~perfectly~ flat and the sukashi so crisp in
execution that it felt almost machined precise in
execution.
    I mentally ruled out Akasaka, and was curious to
see the shinsa results on it. The fact that I don't
would point towards either (a) early senility or (b)
that this was the one substituted out.

Jim, (sidenote) at the time I was surprised at the
Myochin call on the other tsuba. I would have thought
that it ended up in some group I was less familiar
with. Interesting tsuba.

Any preview on the Yagyu exhibit for those
international listeroos that won't get to see it?

Curran



--- Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:

> Curran,
> Number 482 was a Myochin tsuba with a circular cross
> section rim and a design of two large diamond shapes
> at 12:00 and 6:00.  That's the only thing similar in
> your group.  I know the owner, so I'm guessing it's
> the one you're thinking of.
> 
> I've seen the spiral motif used on a guard signed
> Tadatoki, and as Rich said the insect is often seen
> in Akasaka sukashi.  I don't think Akasaka is a bad
> call. 
> 
> Rich, what's putting you off Akasaka?
> 
> Back to the Yagyu,
>  Jim
> 
> 
> 
>   Rich,
> 
>   At the Chicago 2004 NTHK Shinsa, I papered a near
>   identical (very pristine condition) tsuba for a
>   friend. I do not remember what the attribution
> was-
>   but I know it was not Akasaka.
> 
>   I do not know if Jim G. has easy access to those
>   records, but I believe the tsuba was somewhere
> between
>   the submissions # 460 to 485.
> 
>   Jim can probably identify it out of hand, but I
>   thought you might also appreciate the Hagihara
> notes
>   on the similar tsuba.
> 
>   Curran
>
